question: What is the main focus of the passage "Tracking the Snow Leopard"?
options: How snow leopards hunt different animals at night
Why snow leopards are moving to lower areas
Why snow leopards are endangered and how people can protect them
How to train snow leopards to live near humans

question: Why are snow leopards very rarely seen?
options: They live in remote mountains and hunt mostly at night
They migrate to the ocean in winter
They always travel in large groups

question: What does paragraph A suggest about how a snow leopard moves while hunting?
options: It moves loudly to scare prey
It moves softly and carefully to avoid making noise
It moves quickly in open fields
It moves only when it rains

question: What is one reason it is difficult to protect snow leopards even though they have been protected since 1975?
options: The law is easy to break and hard to enforce
Snow leopards cannot survive in the wild
People do not know what snow leopards look like
Snow leopards are protected only in zoos

question: According to the passage, why do some people kill snow leopards for illegal trade?
options: Their fur and body parts are worth a lot of money
Their meat is the main food in Central Asia
Their tails are used to build fences
Their spots are used to make paint

question: How does conflict with local herders lead to snow leopard deaths?
options: Snow leopards steal crops from farms
Snow leopards kill livestock, so herders may retaliate
Snow leopards spread disease to villages

question: What does the passage say snow leopards do after killing a herder’s animal?
options: They leave the body in the village
They bury the body under snow
They drag the body high into the mountains to eat
They share the body with wolves

question: What is the estimated current snow leopard population mentioned in the passage?
What do some people fear about the snow leopard population?
options: It has doubled in the last year
It is only found in North America now
It cannot survive above sea level

question: According to conservationists, what is the best way to reverse the decline of snow leopards?
options: Make snow leopards more valuable alive than dead
Stop all travel to Central Asia forever
Remove all livestock from the mountains
Increase the black-market price so fewer people buy

question: Why do traditional cultures in Central Asia depend mostly on livestock?
options: Farming is difficult in the cold, dry landscape
Livestock is easier to hide from tourists
There are no mountains in the region
People are not allowed to grow crops

question: What can happen to a family if it loses even a few animals?
options: It may become famous in the region
It may be pushed into desperate poverty
It may have to move to a bigger farm
It may be protected by the government automatically

question: How do local religious leaders try to help protect snow leopards?
options: They teach snow leopards to avoid villages
They call for an end to killings and emphasize the leopard’s right to exist
They pay hunters to catch more leopards
They encourage people to sell more fur overseas

question: What is the main idea of "The Value of Preservation" section?
options: Financial incentives can reduce snow leopard killings
Snow leopards should be removed from Central Asia
Herders should stop keeping sheep and goats
Night hunting is the only reason snow leopards survive

question: What does the Himalayan Homestays program provide to visitors?
options: A luxury hotel in the city
A room, meals, and a cultural introduction in herders’ homes
A free flight to Central Asia
A hunting license for mountain wildlife

question: About how much do visitors pay per night in the Himalayan Homestays program?
Besides hosting guests, how else does the Homestays organization help herders?
options: It buys snow leopard fur from herders
It builds protective fences and offers environmental classes
It teaches wolves to hunt elsewhere
It replaces all livestock with machines

question: What do herders agree to do in exchange for support from the Homestays program?
options: Kill snow leopards only at night

question: What does Snow Leopard Enterprises (SLE) do in Mongolia?
options: It pays tourists to avoid villages
It buys wool products from herding families and sells them abroad
It builds zoos for snow leopards
It trains snow leopards to guard livestock

question: What condition must communities meet to receive the SLE bonus reward?
options: No one kills protected animals for a full year

question: 「獨特的、有特色的」最適合的英文是？
「難以找到的、不易察覺的」最適合的英文是？
「正式地、官方地」最適合的英文是？
「執行（法令、規定）」最適合的英文是？
「衝突、爭執」最適合的英文是？
「拖拉（重物）」最適合的英文是？
「扭轉、逆轉」最適合的英文是？
「狀態、地位」最適合的英文是？
「地形、景觀」最適合的英文是？
「貧窮」最適合的英文是？
「獎金、紅利」最適合的英文是？
What is the main idea of this passage about Mount Fuji?
options: Mount Fuji is no longer an active volcano
Mount Fuji is both a sacred mountain and a potentially dangerous volcano
Mount Fuji is the only volcano on the Pacific Ring of Fire
Mount Fuji is famous mainly for its wildlife

question: According to paragraph A, what can volcanoes do?
options: Shape lands and cultures but also cause great destruction

question: Where are two of the best-known volcano examples found (paragraph A)?
options: On opposite ends of the world, on the Pacific Ring of Fire

question: When do many climbers hike to reach Mount Fuji’s summit (paragraph B)?
How high is Mount Fuji, according to paragraph B?
What do climbers stop to do near the summit at sunrise (paragraph B)?
options: Watch the sun spread golden rays across the mountain
Build fences to protect the mountain

question: Why is sunrise on Mount Fuji described as an important moment for climbers (paragraph B)?
options: It is the only safe time to climb
It marks the end of the rainy season
They witness the dawn at the highest point in Japan
It proves the volcano is inactive

question: Why is Mount Fuji considered a sacred site (paragraph C)?
options: Shintoism considers it a holy place
It is the coldest mountain in Japan
It contains the largest forest in Japan
It has no history of eruptions

question: What do some people believe about Mount Fuji’s waters (paragraph C)?
options: They can make a sick person well
They are too dangerous to drink

question: Which reason for climbing Mount Fuji is NOT mentioned in paragraph C?
When do hundreds of thousands attempt to climb Mount Fuji (paragraph C)?
What important point does paragraph D add about Mount Fuji?
options: It is far from any large city
It is an active volcano near where many people live
It has never erupted in recorded history
It is the tallest mountain in the world

question: About how many people have settled around Mount Fuji (paragraph D)?
How far is Mount Fuji from Tokyo, according to paragraph D?
What evidence in paragraph E suggests Mount Fuji may erupt again?
options: An increase in activity under Fuji, possibly linked to low-frequency earthquakes
A drop in tourism near the mountain

question: 「不可避免的」最適合的英文是？
「監測、監控」最適合的英文是？
「擴張、擴大」最適合的英文是？
「迫使（人）遷移／使流離失所」最適合的英文是？
「祖先」最適合的英文是？
「安撫／平息（怒氣）」最適合的英文是？

Complete the sentence: Researchers conducting experiments in a ______, as well as those observing animals in the real world, suggest that animals are much more aware of the world around them than human beings.
Complete the sentence: Mitsuaki Ota of Azabu University in Japan claims that dogs can ______ early signs of earthquakes about three hours before they happen.
Complete the sentence: Some scientists are confident that with additional research ______, more precise predictions are possible.
Complete the sentence: Some scientists are confident that with additional research data, more ______ predictions are possible.
This exercise says one word is extra. Which word from the box is NOT used to complete the passage?
At what time does the koala rescue call happen?
Where does the phone ring when the rescue begins?
options: In Megan Aitken’s home in a suburb of Brisbane
In a research station in the desert

question: What does Megan Aitken do?
options: She runs a volunteer organization that rescues wild koalas
She sells eucalyptus leaves to tourists

question: Who are the two other volunteers already at the scene?
options: Jon Hanger and Carlos Valdés González

question: What problem do the rescuers discover when they arrive?
options: The koala has disappeared into the water
The koala’s fur is caught in barbed wire
The koala is trapped inside a tree hollow
The koala is surrounded by wolves

question: Why does Aitken say the koala was trying to get to the other side of the fence?
options: There were tall eucalyptus trees nearby
There was a zoo entrance on the other side
There was a river with fish on the other side
There was a shelter with blankets on the other side

question: Why does Aitken put on heavy gloves?
options: Koalas can bite when they feel threatened
Koalas cannot be held without ice
Koalas only respond to rubber gloves

question: What do the volunteers do to capture the koala safely?
options: They chase it until it gets tired
They lure it with fruit and close a door
They cover it with a blanket and place it into a cage
They spray water to make it fall

question: What do they check right after capturing the koala?
What happens if the koala is sick or injured?
options: It is taken to an animal hospital
It is left in the cage overnight

question: According to the passage, what is typical koala behavior related to living and eating?
options: They migrate long distances every week
They tend to live in a small area and eat from the same trees repeatedly
They live only on beaches and eat fish
They live underground and eat roots

question: What is "the whole problem" Aitken describes in the suburb where she is rescuing the koala?
options: There are almost no trees and few places left for koalas
There are no fences at all

question: What does Aitken do at the end of the rescue scene?
options: She keeps the koala as a pet
She takes the koala to a small park and releases it
She sells the koala to a zoo
She brings the koala to a laboratory for a year

question: According to de Villiers, which is NOT mentioned as a cause of koala deaths?
options: Being hunted for fur by local people

question: How long has de Villiers been studying koalas and their disappearance?
What change does de Villiers recommend to help koalas live with humans in suburban areas?
options: Reduce speed limits and create more green areas
Move all people away from Brisbane

question: What disease issue is described as a major problem for koalas in Queensland?
options: A disease called chlamydiosis affecting almost half of female koalas
A disease caused by volcano ash
A disease that only affects male koalas
A disease that makes koalas eat meat

question: Without treatment, what happens to koalas affected by the disease mentioned?
options: They start living in the ocean

question: What does the infographic "Losing Their Eucalyptus" suggest happened over time?
options: Nearly two-thirds of forests were cleared, leaving far fewer koalas in the wild
Koalas moved from Australia to Europe
Koalas doubled in number because of new highways

question: How does de Villiers locate Tee Vee in the forest near Brisbane?
options: By following footprints in the snow
By listening for a signal from the koala’s radio collar using audio equipment
By using a map of volcanoes
By watching for smoke from trees

question: Complete the sentence: In recent years, human activity has driven the cassowary nearly to ______.
Complete the sentence: They ______ shy away from people, but are seen occasionally in city suburbs.
Complete the sentence: They are seen occasionally in city ______.
Complete the sentence: The birds even fall into traps meant to ______ wild pigs.
Complete the sentence: But it is land development that really ______ cassowaries.
Complete the sentence: Roads carve up the forest, so their ______ habitat is no longer a single area.
1. What is the main idea of paragraph C?
options: Local herders are uncooperative in attempts to save snow leopards.
The snow leopard’s endangerment is due in part to the black market.
Snow leopards are killed for their fur and body parts.
It is difficult to enforce the laws made to protect the snow leopard.

question: 2. In the last sentence of paragraph D, this trend refers to ________.
options: the fall in the snow leopard population
the pressures caused by the black market

question: 3. According to conservationists, what’s the best way to save the snow leopard?
options: create a nature park where they can be free
move herders away from where the snow leopard lives
pass laws to punish people who kill snow leopards for their fur
make people recognize the value of living snow leopards

question: 4. Which of these is NOT true about the Himalayan Homestays program?
options: The organization helps herders to build fences.
Some herders work as nature guides.
Visitors pay a weekly fee to stay at a herder’s house.

question: 5. Why is the Mongolian women’s status in the community “elevated” (paragraph I)?
options: They are saving money for the snow leopards.
They are earning money for the community.
They are living higher up in the mountain.

question: 1. What is paragraph C mainly about?
options: how Mount Fuji became an important religious site
the healing properties of Mount Fuji

question: 2. Which of these statements about Mount Fuji is NOT true?
options: Scientists believe it may erupt soon.
Locals have traditions concerning the mountain.

question: 3. In paragraph G, line 4, the word symptoms could be replaced with _____.
4. What was the reason for the evacuation from El Popo in 2000?
options: People could see smoke and ash.
People saw the surface change shape.

question: 5. Which statement is true about both Mount Fuji and El Popo?
options: They are both less than 100 kilometers from a very large city.
Locals present gifts to both volcanoes for protection.
They both provide rich soil used for producing coffee.

question: 1. What is this reading mainly about?
options: how one woman is saving koalas from extinction
ways that humans and koalas can learn to live together
new methods for studying koalas in the wild
threats to koalas and efforts to protect them

question: 2. What does Megan Aitken use the blanket for?
options: to catch the koala after it falls from a tree
to cover the koala so it doesn’t harm her
to keep the koala warm after it’s placed in the cage
to place over the cage so the koala inside stays calm

question: 3. Why is the koala that Aitken caught released in a nearby park?
options: because koalas feed in the same trees again and again
because it’s the only place nearby that has eucalyptus trees
because that’s where the koala probably has its baby
because wild koalas are not allowed in residential areas

question: 4. According to Deidré de Villiers, what is the main thing that suburban areas must do to protect koalas?
options: lower speed limits in areas with koalas
build green corridors for koala movement

question: 5. Why do you think de Villiers captures Tee Vee?
options: to see if she had her baby
to attach a signaling device to her
to take her to an animal hospital
